# Draft:Battle of Kaer Morhen

= Battle of Kaer Morhen =
The Battle of Kaer Morhen was a major fictional engagement that took place in 1272 in the Witcher universe, during the events of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, developed by CD Projekt Red and based on the novels by Andrzej Sapkowski. It marked a turning point in the conflict between Cirilla (Ciri) and the Wild Hunt, a spectral elven cavalry from another world known as the Aen Elle.

Background
Kaer Morhen, the ancient stronghold of the School of the Wolf, was once a center for witcher training but had long since fallen into ruin and disuse by the time of the battle. Despite this, the fortress still served as a safe haven for the few remaining witchers: Vesemir, Geralt of Rivia, Lambert, and Eskel.
As the Wild Hunt relentlessly pursued Ciri due to her Elder Blood, Geralt rallied allies to mount a defense at Kaer Morhen. Among those who answered the call were powerful sorceresses like Yennefer of Vengerberg and Triss Merigold, along with warriors like Zoltan Chivay, Vernon Roche, Keira Metz, and even the vampire Emiel Regis (depending on player choices).
Prelude
The defenders spent several days preparing the keep’s defenses with magical wards, traps, potions, and alchemical weapons. Tensions were high as the reality of an interdimensional army bearing down on them became imminent. The Wild Hunt, led by Eredin, intended to capture Ciri to harness her powers to conquer space and time.
The Battle
The battle began with the Wild Hunt opening portals into the courtyard of Kaer Morhen, unleashing waves of spectral warriors and frost-based magic. While the defenders fought bravely, the sheer power of the Hunt overwhelmed many of their defenses.
During the assault, Vesemir was killed by Imlerith while trying to protect Ciri. His death was a critical moment, causing Ciri to fully awaken her Elder Blood powers, unleashing a devastating energy wave that forced the Wild Hunt to retreat temporarily.
Aftermath
The battle, though technically a defensive success, left Kaer Morhen heavily damaged and cost the lives of several key allies, most notably Vesemir. The loss deeply affected Ciri and Geralt and became a rallying point for the coming final confrontation with the Wild Hunt.
The conflict shifted the war from passive defense to active pursuit. Ciri, now fully aware of her powers, took the fight to Eredin and his generals.
